overview: What-to-do checklist following a person's death - registering it, coroner's involvement, arranging the funeral and death abroad
title: What to do after someone dies
video_summary: Video on what to do after a death - how to register it, arrange the funeral and other things you need to take care of.

table.body:
When someone dies there are things you must do in the first few days:

s1. **Get a medical certificate** - you'll get this from a doctor (GP or at a hospital) and it's needed to register the death.
s2. **Register the death** - you should do this within 5 days of the death - you'll then get the documents you need for the funeral.
s3. **Arrange the funeral** - you can use a funeral director or do it yourself.

Sorting out the person's affairs, eg selling their property, can be done later - see [Wills, probate and inheritance](/wills-probate-inheritance "Wills, probate and inheritance").
table.title: Overview

table.body:
%If the death has been [reported to a coroner](/after-a-death/when-a-death-is-reported-to-a-coroner "When a death is reported to a coroner") you can't register the death until the coroner gives permission.%

##Who can register the death
You can register the death if you're:

- a relative 
- someone who was present at the death
- the person making the funeral arrangements
- the person who found the body

^The registrar would normally only allow other people to register the death if there are no relatives available.^

##Where to register the death
You should [register the death at a register office](/register-offices "Find a register office") in the area where the person died.

##What you need to register a death
You need to take:

- the medical certificate
- birth and marriage/civil partnership certificates (you can show these to the registrar later)

You need to tell the registrar the person's:

- full name (including any maiden name)
- date and place of birth (town and county if born in the UK and country if born abroad)
- last address
- occupation

You also need the full name, date of birth and occupation of a surviving spouse.

^Tell the registrar if the person was getting a State Pension or any benefits.^

##What documents you get from the registrar

You'll get a:

- Certificate for Burial or Cremation (the ‘green form') - give this to the funeral director
- Certificate of Registration of Death (form BD8) - you complete this if the person was claiming benefits or had a state pension

##Getting a death certificate
You need a death certificate to sort out the person's money, property and possessions.

You can buy one or more death certificates at this time (the cost varies between register offices).
table.title: Register the death

table.body:
A doctor may report the death to a coroner, for example if the:

- cause of death is unknown
- death was violent or unnatural
- death was sudden and unexplained
- doctor caring for the person had not seen them for 14 days before their death

The coroner may decide that the cause of death is clear. In this case:

s1. The doctor signs a medical certificate.
s2. You take the medical certificate to the registrar.
s3. The coroner issues a certificate to the registrar stating a post-mortem isn't needed.


##Post-mortems 
To find out how the person died, the coroner may decide a post-mortem is needed. This can be done either in a hospital or mortuary.

You can't object to a post-mortem - but the coroner must tell you (and the person's GP) when and where the examination will take place.

After the post-mortem:

s1. The coroner will release the body for a funeral once they have completed the post-mortem examinations and no further examinations are needed. 
s2. If the body is released with no inquest, the coroner will send send a form ('Pink Form B - form 101') to the registrar stating the cause of death.
s3. If the body is to be cremated, the coroner will also send a 'Certificate of Coroner - form Cremation 6'.


##If the coroner decides to hold an inquest
A coroner must hold an inquest if the cause of death is still unknown, or if the person: 

- possibly died a violent or unnatural death
- died in prison or police custody

You can't register the death until after the inquest. The coroner is responsible for sending the relevant paperwork to the registrar.
table.title: When a death is reported to a coroner

table.body:
The funeral can usually only take place after the death has been registered.

##Funeral directors
Most people use a funeral director.

Get more than one quote to compare costs. You should choose a funeral director who's a member of either:

- [National Association of Funeral Directors](http://www.nafd.org.uk/funeral-advice/funeral-advice-home.aspx "National Association of Funeral Directors (NAFD)"){:rel="external"}
- [Society of Allied and Independent Funeral Directors](http://www.saif.org.uk/website/index.html "Society of Allied and Independent Funeral Directors"){:rel="external"}

Both organisations have codes of practice and have to give you a price list when asked.

Some local councils run their own [funeral services](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/index.jsp?LGSL=671&LGIL=8&ServiceName=Find%20out%20about%20a%20council%20funeral "Find out about a council funeral"){:rel="external"} - eg non-religious burials.

##Arranging the funeral yourself

To arrange a funeral yourself, contact the Cemeteries and Crematorium Department of your local authority.

##Funeral costs
Funeral costs can include:

- funeral director fees
- things the funeral director pays for on your behalf (called 'disbursements') - eg a newspaper announcement about the death
- local authority burial fees

Often funeral directors list all these costs in their quote.

###Paying for a funeral
The funeral can be paid:

- by you or other family members or friends
- from a financial scheme(s) the person had - eg a pre-paid funeral plan or insurance policy
- from money from the person's estate (eg savings) - getting access to this is called [applying for a 'grant of representation'](/wills-probate-inheritance "Applying for probate") (sometimes called 'applying for probate')

^If you have difficulty paying for the funeral, apply for a [Funeral Payment](/funeral-payments "Applying for a Funeral Payment").^

##Moving a body out of England or Wales
You need to get permission from a coroner to move a body for a funeral abroad. You need to apply at least 4 days before you want the body to be moved.

Find a local coroner using the [Coroners' Society of England and Wales website.](http://www.coronersociety.org.uk/wfOfficeCoroner.aspx "Coroners' Society of England and Wales website"){:rel="external"}
table.title: Arrange the funeral

table.body:
There are several organisations you should contact to tell them about the person's death.

##Government organisations
You may need to contact:

- [HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sf=&sp_scope=hmrc&sc=hmrc&nh=10&sr=0&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx1=&tx0=49640 "HM Revenue & Customs contact details"){:rel="external"}
- the [National Insurance contributions office](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?raction=view&fl0=__dsid%3A&sm=0&ha=34&as=1&sf=&sp_scope=hmrc&sc=hmrc&nh=10&sr=0&cs=ISO-8859-1&tx1=&tx0=49622 "National Insurance contact details"){:rel="external"}  if they were self-employed (to cancel payments)
- the [Child Benefit office](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=5&fl0=contactid:&tx1=&raction=view "Child Benefit office"){:rel="external"} (within 8 weeks of the death)
- the [Tax Credit office](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=60&fl0=contactid:&tx1=&raction=view
"Tax Credit office contact details"){:rel="external"}
- the [DVLA](/tell-dvla-about-bereavement "Telling the DVLA about a bereavement") - eg to return any driving licence and cancel car tax

###Tell us once

Some local authorities run a service called ['Tell Us Once'](/tell-us-once-report-death "Tell Us Once: report a death"). This means they’ll contact the different government services for you - instead of you having to do it yourself.

When you register the death, ask the [registrar](register-the-death "Register the death") if it's available in your area.

###Returning a passport###
If the person had a passport, you should cancel it to prevent it being used illegally. You can return it with the form below or hand it into your nearest [passport office.](http://maps.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/MapAction.do?ref=passportofficesregional#mapanchor "nearest passport office"){:rel="external"}

$D[Download 'What to do with a passport when the passport holder has died'](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/documents/digitalasset/dg_188463.pdf "Download 'What to do with a passport when the passport holder has died'")$D

##The local council

Contact the local council to cancel things like Council Tax and resident parking permits.

##Banks and other financial organisations

You may need to close down (or change the details of) the person's bank accounts or financial schemes - eg mortgage provider, insurance companies and pension provider.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Organisations you need to contact

table.body:
If the person died abroad, the British Consulate in that country can give advice about:

- registering the death - how this is done depends on the country
- arranging for the funeral to be in the country the person died in
- bringing the body back to the UK

^All deaths must be registered in the country where the person died.^

##Bringing the body home

To bring the body home you need:

- a certified English translation of the death certificate
- permission from a coroner (or equivalent) in the country where the person died to remove the body

The British Consulate can help to arrange this.

You can find out more on the [Foreign & Commonwealth Office website.](http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/when-things-go-wrong/death-abroad "Foreign & Commonwealth Office - death abroad information"){:rel="external"}

##Contacting a register office in England and Wales

You need to take the death certificate to the [register office](/register-offices "Search for a register office.") in the area the funeral is taking place. 

As the death has already been registered in the country the person died in, the registrar will give you a 'Certificate of no liability to register'. You should give this to the funeral director so the funeral can go ahead.

##When a coroner is involved

If the person is to be cremated, a certificate from the coroner (form Cremation 6) is needed. 

Whether the person is to be buried or cremated, a coroner will be involved if the cause of death abroad is unknown - or if it was sudden, violent or unnatural.
table.title: Death abroad
